articles.headline: Cellphone Envy Lays Motorola Low
articles.snippet: Motorola is learning a cruel new lesson that a phone’s value reflects not so much what it can do, but whether it is the envy of friends.
articles.abstract: Motorola is learning a cruel new lesson that a phone’s value reflects not so much what it can do, but whether it is the envy of friends.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the sleek Motorola Razr V3 cellphone first hit the stores just over two years ago, it carried the price tag of a must-have status symbol: $500.

articles.headline: From Raider to Activist, but Still Icahn
articles.snippet: At the age of 70, Carl C. Icahn has gone from being a corporate raider to a “shareholder activist.”
articles.abstract: At the age of 70, Carl C. Icahn has gone from being a corporate raider to a “shareholder activist.”
articles.lead_paragraph: “A large number of companies in this country are badly run,” Carl C. Icahn said the other day. “Terribly run. That’s one of the reasons I’m successful.”

articles.headline: Analysis Is Bleak on Iraq’s Future
articles.snippet: A new National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq expressed deep doubts about the abilities of Iraqi officials to hold the country together.
articles.abstract: A new National Intelligence Estimate on Iraq expressed deep doubts about the abilities of Iraqi officials to hold the country together.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 — The release on Friday of portions of a bleak new National Intelligence Estimate about Iraq’s future left the White House and its opponents vying over whether its findings buttressed their vastly different views about how to arrest the worsening sectarian chaos there.

articles.headline: Consumers Have Allies on the Web
articles.snippet: Consumer advocacy takes on renewed power as it moves into a new form, the blog.
articles.abstract: Consumer advocacy takes on renewed power as it moves into a new form, the blog.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ben Popken is an unlikely consumer crusader.

articles.headline: Titillating or Not, Washington Gossip Blossoms
articles.snippet: Never in memory has the political world been so awash in items about every burp and wart of our nation’s leaders.
articles.abstract: Never in memory has the political world been so awash in items about every burp and wart of our nation’s leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2  Some big doings in the nation’s capital this week.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley’s High-Tech Hunt for Colleague
articles.snippet: Silicon Valley’s best and brightest organized a concerted, high-tech effort to find a missing Microsoft researcher.
articles.abstract: Silicon Valley’s best and brightest organized a concerted, high-tech effort to find a missing Microsoft researcher.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 2 — When James Gray failed to return home from a sailing trip on Sunday night, Silicon Valley’s best and brightest went out to help find him.

articles.headline: Viacom Tells YouTube: Hands Off
articles.snippet: YouTube says it will comply with Viacom’s request that it remove more than 100,000 clips from the Web.
articles.abstract: YouTube says it will comply with Viacom’s request that it remove more than 100,000 clips from the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sign of the growing tension between old-line media and the new Internet behemoths, Viacom, the parent company of MTV and Comedy Central, demanded yesterday that YouTube, the video-sharing Web site owned by Google, remove more than 100,000 clips of its programming.
articles.byline: By Geraldine Fabrikant and Saul Hansell

articles.headline: 2nd Acts in the Executive Suite
articles.snippet: Second-act chief executives bring deep knowledge of their industries and their companies, but may be reluctant to make radical changes.
articles.abstract: Second-act chief executives bring deep knowledge of their industries and their companies, but may be reluctant to make radical changes.
articles.lead_paragraph: When James R. Houghton began a second stint as chief executive at Corning Inc. in 2002, the company was reeling. The first thing he did, Mr. Houghton recalled yesterday, was “to see if there was somebody I should shoot.”
articles.byline: By Steve Lohr and Damon Darlin

articles.headline: McCain’s Advisers Once Made Ads  That Drew His Ire
articles.snippet: Senator John McCain’s team includes political bruisers whose work he has criticized as stepping over the line.
articles.abstract: Senator John McCain’s team includes political bruisers whose work he has criticized as stepping over the line.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 — Senator John McCain, intent on succeeding where his freewheeling presidential campaign of 2000 failed, is assembling a team of political bruisers for 2008. And it includes advisers who once sought to skewer him and whose work he has criticized as stepping over the line in the past.

articles.headline: The C.E.O.’s Parachute Cost What?
articles.snippet: Directors are waking up to the full cost, tax included, of executive exit packages.
articles.abstract: Directors are waking up to the full cost, tax included, of executive exit packages.
articles.lead_paragraph: GEORGE W. BUSH sounded off on executive pay last week in a visit to Wall Street. “America’s corporate boardrooms must step up to their responsibilities,” he told the stone-faced titans in attendance. “You need to pay attention to the executive compensation packages that you approve.”

articles.headline: At Least 130 Die as Blast Levels Baghdad Market
articles.snippet: The unrelenting killing of Shiites promises to put more pressure on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq.
articles.abstract: The unrelenting killing of Shiites promises to put more pressure on Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Sunday, Feb. 4 — A mammoth truck bomb obliterated a popular central Baghdad market on Saturday, ripping through scores of shops and flattening apartment buildings, killing at least 130 people and wounding more than 300 in the worst of a series of horrific attacks against Shiites in recent weeks.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Qais Mizher

articles.headline: The Netherlands, the New Tax Shelter Hot Spot
articles.snippet: Forget the Cayman Islands. The new hot spot for tax shelters is the Netherlands, which has drawn assets from the Rolling Stones, U2 and Sun Microsystems.
articles.abstract: Forget the Cayman Islands. The new hot spot for tax shelters is the Netherlands, which has drawn assets from the Rolling Stones, U2 and Sun Microsystems.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oh, a storm is threat’ning My very life today If I don’t get some shelter Oh yeah, I’m gonna fade away

articles.headline: Iranian Boast Is Put to Test
articles.snippet: Setbacks in Tehran’s experimental uranium enrichment program suggest that its bluster may far outstrip its expertise.
articles.abstract: Setbacks in Tehran’s experimental uranium enrichment program suggest that its bluster may far outstrip its expertise.
articles.lead_paragraph: After decades of largely clandestine efforts, Iran is expected to declare in coming days that it has made a huge leap toward industrial-scale production of enriched uranium — a defiant act that the country’s leaders will herald as a major technical stride and its neighbors will denounce as a looming threat. But for now, many nuclear experts say, the frenetic activity at the desert enrichment plant in Natanz may be mostly about political showmanship.
articles.byline: By William J. Broad and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Thinks Big About the Little Guy
articles.snippet: A boss tackles problems of the working poor while reducing turnover and increasing profits.
articles.abstract: A boss tackles problems of the working poor while reducing turnover and increasing profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: IN 1990, Steven T. Bigari was running a string of McDonald’s franchises in Colorado Springs and spending most of his working hours thinking about the big bad wolf at his door, otherwise known as Taco Bell, which was killing his business with a promotional menu of items costing only 59 cents each.

articles.headline: Iraq’s Shadow Widens Sunni-Shiite Split in U.S.
articles.snippet: Sectarian tensions have been blamed for vandalism and student confrontations in American Muslim communities.
articles.abstract: Sectarian tensions have been blamed for vandalism and student confrontations in American Muslim communities.
articles.lead_paragraph: DEARBORN, Mich. — Twice recently, vandals have shattered windows at three mosques and a dozen businesses popular among Shiite Muslims along Warren Avenue, the spine of the Arab community here.

articles.headline: The Director Lines Up a Shot
articles.snippet: A year after DreamWorks was sold to Paramount, Steven Spielberg is fighting to retain control of his company’s independence.
articles.abstract: A year after DreamWorks was sold to Paramount, Steven Spielberg is fighting to retain control of his company’s independence.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 — In December, Brad Grey, the chairman of Paramount Pictures, stood up and greeted the celebrity-packed crowds at the premiere of “Dreamgirls” in Los Angeles and New York. It seemed like an innocent gesture, but executives from DreamWorks SKG, which was brought under Paramount’s control last year and which produced the movie, cried foul.

articles.headline: In New Orleans, Dysfunction Fuels Cycle of Killing
articles.snippet: Hurricane Katrina loosened the fragile social restraints in New Orleans, making the city perhaps more dangerous.
articles.abstract: Hurricane Katrina loosened the fragile social restraints in New Orleans, making the city perhaps more dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4  When the body was brought out, the two little boys did not stop chewing their sticky blue candy or swigging from their pop bottles. The 18-year-old mother wheeling her baby came to watch, and the teenager with the spiky hair and the bulky duffle coat was laughing up on the worn stoop.
articles.byline: By Adam Nossiter and Christopher Drew

articles.headline: New Suitor Ignites Battle for Ailing Mills Corp.
articles.snippet: Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management are planning a $1.56 billion cash bid for the outlet mall developer Mills Corporation.
articles.abstract: Simon Property Group and Farallon Capital Management are planning a $1.56 billion cash bid for the outlet mall developer Mills Corporation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Another major battle has surfaced in the commercial real estate market, this time over the ailing mall developer Mills Corporation.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Super Bowl Ads of Cartoonish Violence, Perhaps Reflecting Toll of War
articles.snippet: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.
articles.abstract: The war in Iraq seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s Super Bowl commercials.
articles.lead_paragraph: No commercial that appeared last night during Super Bowl XLI directly addressed Iraq, unlike a patriotic spot for Budweiser beer that ran during the game two years ago. But the ongoing war seemed to linger just below the surface of many of this year’s commercials.

articles.headline: Skipping Merrily Along as Others Take the Heat
articles.snippet: Robert D. Novak, the writer who first named a C.I.A. spy, has remained on the sidelines of a game he started.
articles.abstract: Robert D. Novak, the writer who first named a C.I.A. spy, has remained on the sidelines of a game he started.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last week was a busy one for the journalists caught up in the Valerie Plame saga three years ago. The trial of I. Lewis Libby, the former chief of staff to Vice President Dick Cheney, included the less than appetizing spectacle of watching experienced reporters explain precisely how the job gets done.

articles.headline: Familiar Face, but a New Tone to the Message
articles.snippet: John Edwards is staking out provocative positions on big issues in an effort to gain an edge in a crowded field.
articles.abstract: John Edwards is staking out provocative positions on big issues in an effort to gain an edge in a crowded field.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 — John Edwards has no intention of getting lost in the shuffle.

articles.headline: A Long-Delayed Ad System Has Yahoo Crossing Its Fingers
articles.snippet: Project Panama is Yahoo’s effort to close the wide gap with Google in the race for search advertising dollars.
articles.abstract: Project Panama is Yahoo’s effort to close the wide gap with Google in the race for search advertising dollars.
articles.lead_paragraph: BURBANK, Calif., Feb. 1 — Starting around 3 p.m. Pacific time on Monday, a group of Yahoo executives will begin shuttling among three “war rooms” at the company’s search marketing unit here.

articles.headline: Internet Boom in China Is Built on Virtual Fun
articles.snippet: Instant messaging and game-playing are major obsessions, now central to Chinese culture.
articles.abstract: Instant messaging and game-playing are major obsessions, now central to Chinese culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China — When Pony Ma, the 35-year-old co-founder of China’s hottest Internet company, sends a message to friends and colleagues, the image that pops up on their screens shows a spiky-haired youth wearing flashy jeans and dark sunglasses.

articles.headline: Iraqis Fault Pace of U.S. Plan in Attack
articles.snippet: A growing number of Iraqis blamed the United States for creating conditions that led to the single worst suicide bombing in the war.
articles.abstract: A growing number of Iraqis blamed the United States for creating conditions that led to the single worst suicide bombing in the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Feb. 4 — A growing number of Iraqis blamed the United States on Sunday for creating conditions that led to the worst single suicide bombing in the war, which devastated a Shiite market in Baghdad the day before. They argued that the Americans had been slow in completing the vaunted new American security plan, making Shiite neighborhoods much more vulnerable to such horrific attacks.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Richard A. Oppel Jr
